body:
Here is a stack trace:

```
#0  0x00007f2b9c66712d in poll () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:81
#1  0x00007f2b9bcfb674 in basic_pollset_maybe_work_and_unlock (exec_ctx=0x7f2b9b22ea50, pollset=0x7f2b8c11fec8, worker=0x7f2b9b22e980, deadline=..., now=...) at src/core/iomgr/pollset_posix.c:579
#2  0x00007f2b9bcfad74 in grpc_pollset_work (exec_ctx=0x7f2b9b22ea50, pollset=0x7f2b8c11fec8, worker_hdl=0x7f2b9b22ea20, now=..., deadline=...) at src/core/iomgr/pollset_posix.c:307
#3  0x00007f2b9bd0bcbe in grpc_completion_queue_pluck (cc=0x7f2b8c11fde0, tag=0x7f2b9b22eb10, deadline=..., reserved=0x0) at src/core/surface/completion_queue.c:459
#4  0x00007f2b9c132f3a in grpc::CompletionQueue::Pluck (this=0x7f2b8c118798, tag=0x7f2b9b22eb10) at src/cpp/common/completion_queue.cc:80
#5  0x00007f2b9d42ec78 in grpc::ClientReader<google::bigtable::v1::ReadRowsResponse>::Read (this=0x7f2b8c118780, msg=0x7f2b8c12dc10) at /usr/local/include/grpc++/impl/codegen/sync_stream.h:150
```

There are similar stack traces provided with some issues. Typically the response from the gRPC team is that this is a server side issue, such as server threads starvation.  Since the server in this cases is bigtable and there is a response of some kind from the server seen in the logs, I am not sure if we can blame the server in this case.

Which version of gRPC are you using?

Did you use GRPC_TRACE=all? I suspect not - I'm not seeing some bits I'd
expect to see - and it'd be useful for tracking this down.

On Tue, May 24, 2016 at 8:52 AM ay60 notifications@github.com wrote:

> Any updates?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/6278#issuecomment-221316189

@ctiller I was having this problem with all versions of gRPC up to this commit below. I have not tried it since. I make builds off the main branch, gRPC version is something like 0.14.

```
commit ab1c84f49506f86cb9590708e777d65a4a2a2f10
Merge: 9ea6027 896ae71
Author: Jan Tattermusch <jtattermusch@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Fri Apr 8 22:42:57 2016 -0700
```

The GRPC_TRACE options that I used are those:

```
GRPC_TRACE=api,channel,http,flowctl,connectivity_state,tcp
```

For some reasons `flowctl` did not show up in the last traces. Not sure why. It seems like it should.

I can try again with the `GRPC_TRACE=all` and the tip of the mainline. Do you think it's worth it to try again? Were there any fixes made in the relevant areas of code in the last month or two?

I think some traces are only logged for debug builds and maybe that is why
the flowctl traces do not show up.

> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe/AJp0CrKWQZZrWOISUay2FZ7uZLa6dLbPks5qHF6EgaJpZM4IPNAi
> .

It'd be worthwhile to do another trace: with just 'tcp' we're only seeing
encrypted bytes. 'all' or adding 'secure_endpoint' will let us see the
decrypted bytes also, and let us ascertain what HTTP2 bytes were put onto
the wire. 'all' also includes 'channel' which will let us see a little more
of what's going on in the gRPC stack.

Thanks! I'll give it another try today with `all` option and using the latest code too. Will do the debug build.

Here is the latest case. `GRPC_TRACE=all` was used. gRPC C++  code at

```
commit 0d6196025e62aea5aabc6341459f2c370e264230
Merge: 704fb3f 05e8c9a
Author: Craig Tiller <ctiller@google.com>
Date:   Tue May 31 10:20:20 2016 -0700
```

The call is still the same `ReadRows` Bigtable streaming call.
Note the 10 seconds time gap from 19:17:56 to 19:18:06. That's the hanging. The read call returns after 10 seconds deadline timeout. Let me know if you want to see more of the log.

```
I0531 19:17:56.279246413  113246 call.c:1504]                grpc_call_start_batch(call=0x7fe0e42588f0, ops=0x7fe0f2b2a650, nops=2, tag=0x7fe0f2b2a940, reserved=(nil))
I0531 19:17:56.279262421  113246 call.c:1215]                ops[0]: RECV_INITIAL_METADATA ptr=0x7fe0f2b2a968
I0531 19:17:56.279273483  113246 call.c:1215]                ops[1]: RECV_MESSAGE ptr=0x7fe0f2b2a990
I0531 19:17:56.279287567  113246 client_channel.c:109]       OP[client-channel:0x7fe0e4258e50]: RECV_INITIAL_METADATA RECV_MESSAGE

I0531 19:17:56.279333258  113246 connected_channel.c:70]     OP[connected:0x7fe0e4260ed8]: RECV_INITIAL_METADATA RECV_MESSAGE
D0531 19:17:56.279349498  113246 chttp2_transport.c:1774]    FLOW       op: client stream[3657] CREDIT             global.max_recv_bytes(65535) by                add_max_recv_bytes(65535) giving 131070
D0531 19:17:56.279364301  113246 chttp2_transport.c:1777]    FLOW       op: client stream[3657] CREDIT global.unannounced_incoming_window_for_parse(0) by                add_max_recv_bytes(65535) giving 65535
D0531 19:17:56.279925298  113246 chttp2_transport.c:1780]    FLOW       op: client stream[3657] CREDIT global.unannounced_incoming_window_for_writing(0) by                add_max_recv_bytes(65535) giving 65535
D0531 19:17:56.279952770  113246 writing.c:146]              FLOW    write: client stream[3657] MOVE                 writing.announce_window(0) <- global.unannounced_incoming_window_for_writing(65535) giving 65535
D0531 19:17:56.279972259  113246 writing.c:225]              FLOW    write: client stream[3657] DEBIT            writing.announce_window(65535) by                          announce(65535) giving 0
D0531 19:17:56.279986834  113246 secure_endpoint.c:259]      WRITE 0x7fe0e4266690: 00 00 04 08 00 00 00 0e 49 00 00 ff ff '........I....'
D0531 19:17:56.280017150  113246 tcp_posix.c:401]            WRITE 0x7fe0e4259b20 (peer=ipv4:64.233.182.219:443): 17 03 03 00 25 00 00 00 00 00 00 11 32 84 34 37 89 da 8c 5a f7 e9 ae 1d ca 70 fb b5 47 62 77 be 14 75 c0 84 ff 2b 93 ab 65 2e '....%.......2.47...Z.....p..Gbw..u...+..e.'
I0531 19:17:56.280096101  113246 completion_queue.c:405]     grpc_completion_queue_pluck(cc=0x7fe0e41208b0, tag=0x7fe0f2b2a940, deadline=gpr_timespec { tv_sec: 9223372036854775807, tv_nsec: 0, clock_type: 1 }, reserved=(nil))
D0531 19:17:56.289603747  113246 tcp_posix.c:163]            read: success=1
D0531 19:17:56.289663844  113246 tcp_posix.c:167]            READ 0x7fe0e4259b20 (peer=ipv4:64.233.182.219:443): 17 03 03 00 27 00 00 00 00 00 01 43 ae f0 0b 74 af e2 95 e0 99 85 e0 23 22 41 f2 35 6f f6 92 ec 43 5f fc b4 8a 2b 78 f1 89 f7 11 8a '....'......C...t.......#"A.5o...C_...+x.....'
D0531 19:17:56.289712529  113246 secure_endpoint.c:135]      READ 0x7fe0e4266690: 00 00 06 01 04 00 00 0e 49 88 ea e9 be e7 e6 '........I......'
D0531 19:17:56.289755660  113246 parsing.c:98]               FLOW    parse: client stream[3657] MOVE             parsing.incoming_window(65535) <- global.unannounced_incoming_window_for_parse(65535) giving 131070
I0531 19:17:56.289776704  113246 parsing.c:617]              HTTP:3657:HDR:CLI: :status: 200
I0531 19:17:56.289784898  113246 parsing.c:617]              HTTP:3657:HDR:CLI: content-disposition: attachment
I0531 19:17:56.289790517  113246 parsing.c:617]              HTTP:3657:HDR:CLI: content-type: application/grpc
I0531 19:17:56.289796521  113246 parsing.c:617]              HTTP:3657:HDR:CLI: date: Wed, 01 Jun 2016 02:17:56 GMT

I0531 19:17:56.289831763  113246 parsing.c:617]              HTTP:3657:HDR:CLI: alt-svc: quic=":443"; ma=2592000; v="34,33,32,31,30,29,28,27,26,25"
I0531 19:18:06.277157856  113246 client_channel.c:109]       OP[client-channel:0x7fe0e4258e50]: CANCEL:4
I0531 19:18:06.277194349  113246 http_client_filter.c:143]   OP[http-client:0x7fe0e4260ec0]: CANCEL:4
I0531 19:18:06.277204201  113246 connected_channel.c:70]     OP[connected:0x7fe0e4260ed8]: CANCEL:4
```

@ctiller how is it going? That new trace, is it helpful at all? Any insights to what might be happening? I would be happy to try new things, like do more debugging or make a build off a branch to verify any fixes or attempts at if these are forthcoming. Just let me know.

Hey... I missed this earlier... thanks for pinging.

The last read in the logs is here:
D0531 19:17:56.289712529  113246 secure_endpoint.c:135]      READ 0x7fe0e4266690: 00 00 06 01 04 00 00 0e 49 88 ea e9 be e7 e6 '........I......'

And shows a header frame of length 6 being returned and parsed correctly.

After that there's radio silence: it looks as though the server isn't returning anything.
Does that mean that this is Bigtable server issue? Do we need to get someone from the Bigtable team involved?

@ctiller I have a relevant question. In C++ code base, with the streaming calls, last time I looked, there was no way to set a timeout on an individual read call, only on the whole lifetime of the stream. There is no specific timeout on something like `ClientReader::Read()`, which is what the generated code is using. It is only the `ClientReader()` constructor that sets the deadline. I was going to file an issue asking for a change. I am mentioning that now because to deal with this specific Bigtable problem I am setting deadline but I can not tune that deadline value very well because I have to be conscious of the total possible lifetime of the `ClientReader`. Should I file a different issue? There really should be a way to set an individual timeout on every next `ClientReader::Read()` call.

@ay60  and the cloud bigtable team had a discussion today.  A couple of interesting tidbits came up
1. Once the problem comes up, the "session" (in ay60's terms... I'm assuming that means a Channel) does not work for additional requests.  He has to create a new session in order to perform new RPCs.
2. @ay60 is creating a ReadRowRequest with a range starting at a particular key with an open ended stop key.  He reads some of the streamed responses, and then cancels the call.  We've had some problems in the past with similar requests where the response has not been fully consumed on the client side.  We've run tests with without canceling the call, and we've seen that many of these types of long running, partially consumed response RPCs tickles a server-side flow control issue which OOMs our servers. ay60's case could cause the same issue, and we'll have to test for it.
3. @ay60 has an effective retry mechanism.  Once the old channel gets a timeout after a few seconds and gets into a bad state, his code reconnects and retries the query.  This process works for him, but is not ideal.

We'll definitely do more testing about the "start a scan, read a few rows, cancel, repeat" scenario.  It could be another case that isn't handled effectively on our end.

In the short term, perhaps the best way forward is to work on an approach that doesn't invoke the potential OOM.  That may involve a bit of Bigtable schema or query design which will allow better targeting of range scans.  We'd be glad to brainstorm on that front.

Just to clarify. I am not sure if any of the scans that the app is doing can be qualified as "large scan". The test suite inserts the total of about 700 records in the database. The scan keys are not open-ended on the lower boundary. Still, even if they are, there are no more that 700 rows to read for every read.  And looking at the gRPC trace, grepping for len=[0-9]\* field in the MutateRow call, just to make sure we are not sending crazy sized records to Bigtable, I am getting an average value of 126. This is not a huge data set by any means.
I removed the word large.  The issue of "start a scan, read a few rows, cancel, repeat" still needs some investigation on our end.

Hi, I am facing a problem where my client hangs at CompletionQueueSafeHandle.Pluck(). I was looking for any reports of a similar problem and I found this, so it may or may not be related. I have described the problem I am facing in this post:

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/grpc-io/1t5UC8lPnxs

I was trying to understand what might be causing the issue - and I wondered whether it is something to do with using pointers as tags. I don't understand what these tags are used for but is it possible that every so often the tags conflict? I may be talking nonsense here.

Regards
Dibyendu
Closing as obsolete. Please reopen if this reoccurs.
